The cations and anions in an ionic crystal are
arranged in a systematic, periodic 3-D array 
that maximizes the attractive forces among 
cations and anions while minimizing the 
repulsive forces.

CF676E13058D4533800E35F6173E3413.description:
Represent an ionic solid with
a particulate model that is
consistent with Coulomb’s
law and the properties of the
constituent ions.

777F1ACC69E748ABB24977E7DC18A7A8.description:
Because the interaction strength increases
as the distance between the centers of the
ions (nuclei) decreases, smaller ions lead to
stronger interactions.

61B223A1C5854CEFB30EAB37DFE82A7E.description:
Because the interaction strength is
proportional to the charge on each ion, larger
charges lead to stronger interactions.

72E8605229B641ADB2F9D6CF33B5ECA7.description:
Coulomb’s law can be used to understand the
strength of interactions between cations
and anions.

FDDE4FD4CACE410CAF739832A5BCC244.description:
In a covalent bond, the bond length is
influenced by both the size of the atom’s core 
and the bond order (i.e., single, double, triple).
Bonds with a higher order are shorter and have
larger bond energies.

C48B47802A7841BCAAB69BEECD6D7FAF.description:
A graph of potential energy versus the distance
between atoms (internuclear distance) is
a useful representation for describing the
interactions between atoms. Such graphs
illustrate both the equilibrium bond length
(the separation between atoms at which the
potential energy is lowest) and the bond energy
(the energy required to separate the atoms).

F8ACFDFEED004326ACD466B50A2079AE.description:
Represent the relationship
between potential energy
and distance between
atoms, based on factors that
influence the interaction 
strength.

F711460A1BD74B789BE8712715ED034F.description:
In a metallic solid, the valence electrons
from the metal atoms are considered to be
delocalized and not associated with any 
individual atom.

119C89248C96484EBA3A9AB9A7723882.description:
The difference in electronegativity is not the 
only factor in determining if a bond should
be designated as ionic or covalent. Generally,
bonds between a metal and nonmetal are
ionic, and bonds between two nonmetals are
covalent. Examination of the properties of a
compound is the best way to characterize the 
type of bonding.

FEF0AE8C9E5442DABC3C85897345AD1F.description: All polar bonds have some ionic character, and the difference between ionic and covalent bonding is not distinct but rather a continum

0B2E7FC3A8914A56BB5921891B52BCD5.description:
In   single bonds, greater differences in 
electronegativity lead to greater bond dipoles.

272B7283AAF84EE58BDCFC35DEDE1F43.description:
The atom with a higher electronegativity will
develop a partial negative charge relative to
the other atom in the bond.

F376F1933AA646F8BC5530C80F7415DD.description:
Valence electrons shared between atoms of
unequal electronegativity constitute a polar
covalent bond.

145DA2A063124C20804D54D57C7B92FD.description:
Valence electrons shared between atoms
of similar electronegativity constitute a
nonpolar covalent bond. For example, bonds
between carbon and hydrogen are effectively 
nonpolar even though carbon is slightly more
electronegative than hydrogen.

BF61FE82BB0240BDA2B1ABE6B7134413.description:
Electronegativity values for the representative
elements increase going from left to right
across a period and decrease going down
a group. These trends can be understood
qualitatively through the electronic structure of
the atoms, the shell model, and Coulomb’s law.

AC9F83D6F16B46F580C7ABB0B8C56F00.description:
Explain the relationship
between the type of bonding
and the properties of the
elements participating in
the bond.

EA70F9E65B8543D7A0611AA5D246FC27.description:
Typical charges of atoms in ionic compounds
are governed by the number of valence
electrons and predicted by their location on the
periodic table.

0331338927FB48FD999FC219AB2AE121.description:
Elements in the same column of the periodic
table tend to form analogous compounds.

9C7257CF4D2643F7A49C1E1C2D10F316.description:
The likelihood that two elements will form
a chemical bond is determined by the
interactions between the valence electrons
and nuclei of elements.

9EC68D5C0B9E4A20A11734D45A8E6F40.description:
Explain the relationship
between trends in the
reactivity of elements
and periodicity.

D833AAC08C86451B820523847F9CEA80.description:
The periodicity (in 1.7.A.2) is useful to predict/
estimate values of properties in the absence
of data.

B1FF613FE0CD4C968AE621F460031E5A.description:
Trends in atomic properties within the periodic
table (periodicity) can be predicted by the
position of the element on the periodic table
and qualitatively understood using Coulomb’s
law, the shell model, and the concepts of
shielding and effective nuclear charge. These 
properties include:

EC6A9812B8164ECABA613BE3C0C9BEE4.description:
The organization of the periodic table is based on 
patterns of recurring properties of the elements,
which are explained by patterns of ground-state 
electron configurations and the presence of 
completely or partially filled shells (and subshells) 
of electrons in atoms.

72C462500197403EAF862B9A17C7A21F.description:
Explain the relationship
between trends in atomic
properties of elements and
electronic structure
and periodicity.

C176F592B8B1489D99D2251526C183C5.description:
The energies of the electrons in a given
shell can be measured experimentally with
photoelectron spectroscopy (PES). The
position of each peak in the PES spectrum is
related to the energy required to remove an
electron from the corresponding subshell,
and the relative height of each peak is (ideally)
proportional to the number of electrons in that
subshell.

89A4B228734348B984101F8068850B9F.description:
Explain the relationship
between the photoelectron
spectrum of an atom or
ion and:
i.  The ground-state electron 
configuration of the 
species.
ii. The interactions
between the electrons 
and the nucleus.

7372242D12344767B6570EA55E8A42BE.description:
The relative energy required to remove an
electron from different subshells of an atom or 
ion or from the same subshell in different atoms 
or ions (ionization energy) can be estimated 
through a qualitative application of Coulomb’s
law. This energy is related to the distance from
the nucleus and the effective (shield) charge of 
the nucleus.

309CEC4A57DB4E34BC23B0EB1E24692A.description:
In atoms and ions, the electrons can be
thought of as being in “shells (energy levels)”
and “subshells (sublevels),” as described by
the ground-state electron configuration. Inner 
electrons are called core electrons, and outer
electrons are called valence electrons. The
electron configuration is explained by quantum 
mechanics, as delineated in the Aufbau principle
and exemplified in the periodic table of the 
elements.

88DA1304B30E46268593F2F2043538B5.description:
Coulomb’s law is used to calculate the force
between two charged particles.

AEB3DA6C0FE0452C9B714ABE783E359D.description:
The atom is composed of negatively charged
electrons and a positively charged nucleus that
is made of protons and neutrons.

A6DC100663A24E66BA03BF5B0298D9BC.description:
Represent the ground-state 
electron configuration of an 
atom of an element or its ions
using the Aufbau principle.

5CF7C7C48ABF44D0B22F2D29A2C18EC6.description:
Elemental analysis can be used to determine
the relative numbers of atoms in a substance
and to determine its purity.

ECA27A44DDDE4F96BF41CCAB0F79E945.description:
Pure substances contain atoms, molecules,
or formula units of a single type. Mixtures
contain atoms, molecules, or formula units of
two or more types, whose relative proportions
can vary.

197902272926424AA0AF67461779D83E.description:
Explain the quantitative
relationship between the
elemental composition by
mass and the composition of
substances in a mixture.

A61CD71A2DFC48FCA81F188D43D2D38E.description:
The chemical formula that lists the lowest
whole number ratio of atoms of the elements in
a compound is the empirical formula.

8E687EE15B9B449C9454EA882FB7E25B.description:
According to the law of definite proportions, 
the ratio of the masses of the constituent
elements in any pure sample of that compound
is always the same.

19D4B46D079D4DFA9303B8DE76E3DE29.description:
Some pure substances are composed of
individual molecules, while others consist
of atoms or ions held together in fixed 
proportions as described by a formula unit.

6C0BA985EC524F5B938007032ED4DE55.description:
Explain the quantitative
relationship between the
elemental composition by
mass and the empirical
formula of a pure substance.

1A20E13E0EE341C28E1B6236C0C55B27.description:
The average atomic mass of an element can
be estimated from the weighted average of
the isotopic masses using the mass of each
isotope and its relative abundance.

B15DC07C72EC4D9CBD7704D9F8A28249.description:
The mass spectrum of a sample containing a
single element can be used to determine the
identity of the isotopes of that element and the
relative abundance of each isotope in nature.

1A419491870444CDBDC21C4C9230EF75.description:
Explain the quantitative
relationship between the
mass spectrum of an element
and the masses of the
element’s isotopes.

CA3F7D63E8A54F22A3F3779F3AB1F319.description:
Expressing the mass of an individual atom
or molecule in atomic mass units (amu) is
useful because the average mass in amu of
one particle (atom or molecule) or formula
unit of a substance will always be numerically
equal to the molar mass of that substance
in grams. Thus, there is a quantitative
connection between the mass of a substance
and the number of particles that the
substance contains.

EB9411A2979E4E4EB5EF3D1887DD0FBA.description:
Avogadro’s number (N = 6.022 × 1023 mol−1
)
provides the connection bet A
ween the number
of moles in a pure sample of a substance and
the number of constituent particles (or formula
units) of that substance.

9657920A189D42DE947EF4C6D61E5B8B.description:
One cannot count particles directly while
performing laboratory work. Thus, there must
be a connection between the masses of
substances reacting and the actual number of
particles undergoing chemical changes.

2EE0E7070EBB462A8675A47E27BF5D9A.description:
Calculate quantities of a
substance or its relative
number of particles using
dimensional analysis and the
mole concept.

58551273EF374D8AA9C616962284C802.description:
Explain how potential sources 
of experimental error may affect the 
experimental results.

D5032AB95CFD42DA8B3E85165A044E1A.description:
Explain the connection between 
experimental results and chemical
concepts, processes, or theories.

1A1BD5000CB74C0D9EE7A21C105BCD03.description:
Provide reasoning to justify a claim 
using connections between particulate
and macroscopic scales or levels.

296211A5D9404F35B7852C0F176A7BC5.description:
Provide reasoning to justify a claim 
using chemical principles or laws, or
using mathematical justification.

2452087077A546FEAF2361D9DC49D5E3.description:
Support a claim with evidence 
from representations or models at the
particulate level, such as the structure of
atoms and/or molecules.

D775F9421109418DAEFED268EC895FBE.description:
Support a claim with evidence from 
experimental data.

A3984890DB9E48B8BD9BE42C47CF521D.description:
Argumentation: Develop an explanation or
scientific argument.

AA391BB4C8244C66B5262C206B99E007.description:
Calculate, estimate, or predict 
an unknown quantity from known
quantities by selecting and following
a logical computational pathway and
attending to precision (e.g., performing 
dimensional analysis and attending to 
significant figures).

87EBD1665D3A463EA2F1181734136CB8.description:
Determine a balanced chemical 
equation for a given chemical
phenomenon.

EF7253382C92469792B7D05B37E5E945.description:
Identify information presented 
graphically to solve a problem.

AA214B0D7C7C4C798963F67692BEB113.description:
Explain the relationship between 
variables within an equation when one
variable changes.

EE1FEFB4EC4B4A78AF859C1B2EA418ED.description:
Identify an appropriate theory, 
definition, or mathematical relationship 
to solve a problem.

0E18C7210D3A456398FCD956D53BBA64.description:
Identify quantities needed to solve 
a problem from given information (e.g.,
text, mathematical expressions, graphs,
or tables).

FB5EC72749FB4D869AC640FB2B4EC83E.description: Mathematical Routines: Solve problems using mathematical relationships.

FC3938CE0C7F45F4B24E35E3118D71D4.description:
Explain the degree to which a 
model or representation describes the
connection between particulate-level 
properties and macroscopic properties.

640C5D66C4AF4BA0AC8EDB01D88025F7.description:
Explain the connection between 
particulate-level and macroscopic 
properties of a substance using models
and representations.

3A89978B8D094B2485E87948D15F98C9.description:
Explain whether a model is 
consistent with chemical theories.

685E075F86D349C3A75922A765762192.description:
Predict and/or explain chemical 
properties or phenomena (e.g., of atoms
or molecules) using given chemical
theories, models, and representations.

D5B61267202541ED93E2D9E4F138AA63.description:
Model Analysis: Analyze and interpret models and representations on
a single scale or across multiple scales.

E7D8D51805AF441FA88F5CE3D313AD21.description:
Represent visually the relationship 
between the structures and interactions
across multiple levels or scales (e.g.,
particulate to macroscopic).

6C14ED167CA74C319E8773C3600D6542.description:
Represent chemical substances or 
phenomena with appropriate diagrams
or models (e.g., electron configuration).

4E0DF0F0A0F14C719FF5D66C66580285.description:
Representing Data
and Phenomena: Create representations or models of chemical
phenomena.

AF2C066EC3F14219A5FF7BFF212D1AB2.description:
Explain how modifications 
to an experimental procedure will 
alter results.

1E0BE5E33A5B4D1986D67481DFB773CA.description:
Identify or describe potential 
sources of experimental error.

C61CC8281AE04663A15A0A47E1A3455C.description:
Make observations or collect 
data from representations of 
laboratory setups or results, while 
attending to precision where
appropriate.

1D283411EDB74ED9B0075A3921CA6196.description:
Identify experimental procedures 
that are aligned to a scientific question 
(which may include a sketch of a
lab setup).

1D3A71F0078A48FFAA92051A78A25151.description:
Formulate a hypothesis or predict 
the results of an experiment.

05F12B0B506F431EA7C61EECE4A77689.description:
Identify a testable scientific 
question based on an observation,
data, or a model.

50C609B3CEB4481D9E4E0C942BBDF892.description:
Question and Method: Determine scientific questions
and methods.

231B3862383043EA9D23D08C503BEDE4.description:
Describe the components of and 
quantitative information from models
and representations that illustrate
both particulate-level and macroscopiclevel properties.

D720062F32F9416EA1006885C1FFF163.description:
Describe the components of and 
quantitative information from models
and representations that illustrate
particulate-level properties only.

ABBA3415A4054D83962EBA734C8E7537.description:
Models and Representations: Describe models and representations, including
across scales.
